content: Take your dog to the veterinarian for initial shots and an annual check-up. Regular veterinary care is essential to protect your dog’s health, so good dog owners take their dogs to the vet at least once per year for a checkup and make sure their dogs are up to date on their shots. When you first get your dog, you should take him to the veterinarian for his first check-up and initial shots as well. Then, make sure that you take your dog to the veterinarian once per year for a checkup and updates on shots. [1] Observe your dog for signs of a health issue. Being a good dog owner also means taking your dog to the veterinarian right away if you suspect that he is having a health issue. If you notice that your dog seems sick or that his behavior has changed, schedule an appointment with your veterinarian right away to find out what is going on. Administer flea, tick, and heartworm prevention medications as needed. Flea, tick, and heartworm medications are necessary to protect your dog from preventable health problems. Make sure that you administer these medications as recommended by your veterinarian along with any other medications that your veterinarian prescribes for your dog. [2] Spay or neuter your dog. This helps stem the tide of companion-animal overpopulation. Spaying female dogs reduces the stress and discomfort endured during heat cycles, eliminates the risk of uterine cancer, and greatly reduces the risk of mammary cancer. Neutering makes male dogs much less likely to roam or fight and prevents the small risk of testicular cancer. However, simply calming your dog during her heats, having a fence, supervising your dog and training them properly can reduce or eliminate many of these behaviour-related concerns. Alternative options are available, too, such as vasectomy, neutering, tubal ligation and ovary-sparing spay (OSS). While harder to come by, they come with less long term health risks than spaying and neutering. Spaying and neutering comes with many associated health risks such as different types of cancers, orthopedic disorders and cardiac hemangiosarcoma. [3] License your dog . Getting your dog licensed and purchasing dog tags for him/her is important in case he/she ever runs away or gets lost. It doesn’t cost much to license your dog and in most states you are required to license your dog and keep his/her tags on his/her collar at all times. Not doing so may cost you up to $250. [4] Your dog’s tags should include his name, and your phone number or street address. You may also consider microchipping your dog to increase your chances of finding him/her if he/she runs away or gets lost. Your veterinarian can inject a microchip with a tracking number on it that can be scanned in the event that your dog gets lost and ends up in a shelter. [5] Wash your dog as needed. If your dog has short hair, give your dog a bath once every three months. If your dog has long hair, you may need to bathe him/her more often. To wash your dog, wet all of your dog’s fur with a spray hose or a pitcher, but do not wet the areas around his/her eyes, ears, and nose. Then, massage some shampoo into your dog’s fur. After you have worked the shampoo into a lather, rinse out all of the shampoo. The water should run clear and without suds. Then, dry him/her off with a towel. [6] Don’t use human shampoo on your dog, because some ingredients in human products can be irritating to dogs. Use a special dog shampoo when you wash your dog. Offer your dog plenty of praise and a treat after baths to help him/her develop positive feelings about bath time. Brush your dog. If your dog has short hair, you may only need to brush him/her once a week. If your dog has long hair, you will need to brush him/her every day in order to avoid tangled and matted fur. Use a wide comb to help remove tangles before moving on to a brush. Make sure that you offer your dog lots of praise while you brush him/her and give him/her a treat when you are finished so that he/she will be willing to let you brush him/her on a regular basis. [7] Clip your dog's nails. To clip your dog’s nails, you will need to get a special nail clipper for dogs. You can purchase dog nail clippers in a pet store. You may also need to get your dog used to you handling his nails before you try to clip them. If your dog is wary of you touching his/her feet and nails, help him/her get used to it by petting his/her feet and touching his/her toes. Give him/her praise and a treat when he/she lets you touch his/her toes. After he/she becomes more comfortable with you touching his/her feet, you can try to clip his/her nails. [8] Make sure that you do not cut too far down or you may hit the quick of his/her nail. This area is very sensitive and may cause bleeding. If you are concerned about hurting your dog while trimming his/her nails, ask your vet to show you how or have a professional groomer trim your dog’s nails for you. Brush your dog’s teeth. Brushing your dog’s teeth can help to prevent problems with tooth decay and gum disease as your dog ages. If your dog has bad breath, it may indicate that there is excess bacteria causing a problem. Take your dog to have his/her teeth cleaned by a veterinarian and then follow your veterinarian’s instructions for cleaning his/her teeth. You can use a child’s toothbrush, a gauze pad, or even a bit of nylon stretched over your finger to clean your dog’s teeth. Make sure that you use a special dog toothpaste or mix some baking soda with a bit of water to form a paste. [9] Inspect your dog for problems during grooming times. Grooming time is a good time to check your dog for fleas, ticks, and other potential health problems. Make sure that you inspect your dog’s skin for any unusual growths, wounds, or tender areas. You should also check your dog’s ears for excessive wax buildup and foul odors. If you find anything that seems abnormal, schedule an appointment with your veterinarian as soon as possible. [10] Understand your dog’s dietary requirements. The amount and frequency of your dog’s feedings will depend on the age and size of your dog. Talk to your veterinarian if you are unsure about how much you should be feeding your dog. In general, adult dogs only need to be fed once per day and the amount they need is based on their weight. You can usually find weight charts on dog food packages that indicate how much food your dog needs each day. [11] Keep in mind that dogs under the age of one will need to be fed more frequently. Puppies from 8-12 weeks old need to be fed four times per day. They also require special puppy food. Check with your veterinarian to be sure that you are giving your dog the right type and amount of food every day. [12] Make sure your dog always has access to fresh clean water. Dogs need plenty of fresh clean water to drink every day. Your dog may need more water if he has been exercising or if the weather is hot. Make sure to provide a bowl of water that your dog can access easily. Refill it if the water gets low, and change the water daily. [13] Give treats for good behavior. It’s nice to indulge your dog with a treat now and then to show that you care about him/her. Treats can be used to reward good behavior as well. Reward your dog with a treat every day, such as a dog biscuit or a rawhide bone. Walk your dog every day. Dogs require daily exercise to be healthy and happy. Walking your dog every day is great way to help your dog get the exercise he/she needs. Your dog’s exercise needs will vary based on his/her breed, which means that some dogs will be content with a quick walk around the neighborhood, while others will require at least an hour of walking every day. [14] Consider your dog’s energy level to determine how much and how often you should be walking him/her. Play with your dog. Since not all dogs can do what they were bred to do, such as hunt or dig, it is important to play with them every day to keep them from forming destructive behaviors. Take your dog outside every day for a game of fetch or play tug of war with a special rope toy. Just make sure that you are doing something to stimulate your dog’s body and mind every day to prevent boredom. [15] Give your dog plenty of opportunities to go outside. In addition to daily walks and playtime, your dog may benefit from freedom to go outside a few times every day. An enclosed backyard or a long line are ideal so that your dog can run and explore his/her domain. If you let your dog out and do not join him/her outside, make sure to check on him/her from time to time. If your dog often spends time outside during the warmer months, make sure that he/she has a shady place to get out of the sun and plenty of fresh, clean water and food. [16] Consider enrolling your dog in an obedience course. Good dog owners put in the time and effort that is needed to train their dog basic commands. An obedience course can help you teach your dog some basic obedience skills such as sit, stay, and lay down. Going through an obedience course with your dog can also help you to build a better bond with your dog, which will benefit both of you. [17] You may also consider working one-on-one with a certified professional dog trainer. This is a good option if your dog is not a big fan of other dogs and people, or if you just want more attention and help from the trainer. Keep training sessions short and regular. For the best results, train your dog in short sessions and repeat the sessions regularly. One way that you can train is by doing 5-15 repetitions of a behavior, such as teaching your dog to sit. Then, switch to a different behavior, and then another. Do these repetitions during one 15 minute session every day. Keeping training sessions short will help your dog pay attention. The frequency of your training sessions will help reinforce what you want your dog to learn. [18] Use positive reinforcement. To teach your dog to do what you want him/her to do, it is important to reward his/her good behavior as soon as he does it. For example, if you ask you dog to sit and he/she does, praise and pet him/her right away so that your dog knows that he/she did something good. Try to reward your dog whenever he/she does good things so that he/she knows that these are the behaviors you like. [19] Ignore bad behavior. Teach your dog to stop doing bad behaviors by ignoring him/her when he/she is naughty. For example, if your dog wants to go for a walk and he/she is jumping on you to let you know, ignore him/her and wait until he/she stops jumping. When he/she stops and stands still, put on his/her leash and take him/her for a walk. Repeat this process every time you walk your dog to help him/her understand that you do not want him/her to jump. He/she will learn that jumping up and down does not lead to a walk, but standing still does. [20] Never hit or scream at your dog if he/she does something bad. Punishing your dog in this way does not solve the problem and it may even make the problem worse. Consult an animal behaviorist or certified professional dog trainer if you are having problems with training your dog. Provide your dog with plenty of toys. Good dog owners make sure that their dogs have toys to play with. Make sure that your dog has plenty of toys to keep him stimulated and happy. Some good options are chew toys, squeaky toys, rope toys, frisbees, and tennis balls. Find out what your dog likes best and make sure he/she has some favorite toys to play with at all times. Give your dog a soft spot to sleep every night. Good dog owners don’t make their dogs sleep on the bare floor or outside in the cold. Make sure that you invest in a nice soft doggy bed for your dog when you first get him/her and line it with a blanket. Wash the blanket regularly to keep it clean and dry. Keep your dog’s bed in a warm part of the house that is free from drafts. [21] Shower your dog with love and affection. Dogs provide their humans with love, affection, and companionship, so why not return the favor? If you really want to be a good dog owner, make sure that you shower your dog with lots of love and affection. Pet him/her, praise him/her, and do nice things for him/her so that he/she knows that you care.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner">How to Be a Good Dog Owner</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Protecting_Your_Dog.E2.80.99s_Health_sub" id="">Protecting Your Dog’s Health</a>

<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>. Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">22 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Seeing to your dog’s every need is a lot of work, but well worth the effort. If you want to be a good dog owner, there are some simple things that you do for your dog. Some of the things that good dog owners do include taking your dog for regular check-ups, giving your dog baths, providing plenty of fun toys for your dog, and teaching your dog some basic obedience commands. Being a good dog owner takes time and patience, but your dog will thank you with love and affection.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Protecting_Your_Dog.E2.80.99s_Health_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Protecting_Your_Dog.E2.80.99s_Health">Protecting Your Dog’s Health</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ce893e27fa" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ce893e27fa')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take your dog to the veterinarian for initial shots and an annual check-up.</b> Regular veterinary care is essential to protect your dog’s health, so good dog owners take their dogs to the vet at least once per year for a checkup and make sure their dogs are up to date on their shots. When you first get your dog, you should take him to the veterinarian for his first check-up and initial shots as well. Then, make sure that you take your dog to the veterinarian once per year for a checkup and updates on shots.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Observe your dog for signs of a health issue. Being a good dog owner also means taking your dog to the veterinarian right away if you suspect that he is having a health issue. If you notice that your dog seems sick or that his behavior has changed, schedule an appointment with your veterinarian right away to find out what is going on.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ea7aabeeea" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ea7aabeeea')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Administer flea, tick, and heartworm prevention medications as needed.</b> Flea, tick, and heartworm medications are necessary to protect your dog from preventable health problems. Make sure that you administer these medications as recommended by your veterinarian along with any other medications that your veterinarian prescribes for your dog.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_7f88720877" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7f88720877')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Spay or neuter your dog.</b> This helps stem the tide of companion-animal overpopulation. Spaying female dogs reduces the stress and discomfort endured during heat cycles, eliminates the risk of uterine cancer, and greatly reduces the risk of mammary cancer. Neutering makes male dogs much less likely to roam or fight and prevents the small risk of testicular cancer.

<ul>
<li>However, simply calming your dog during her heats, having a fence, supervising your dog and training them properly can reduce or eliminate many of these behaviour-related concerns.</li>
<li>Alternative options are available, too, such as vasectomy, neutering, tubal ligation and ovary-sparing spay (OSS). While harder to come by, they come with less long term health risks than spaying and neutering. Spaying and neutering comes with many associated health risks such as different types of cancers, orthopedic disorders and cardiac hemangiosarcoma.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a36f00a416" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a36f00a416')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Avoid-Losing-Your-Dog" title="Avoid Losing Your Dog">License your dog</a>.</b> Getting your dog licensed and purchasing dog tags for him/her is important in case he/she ever runs away or gets lost. It doesn’t cost much to license your dog and in most states you are required to license your dog and keep his/her tags on his/her collar at all times. Not doing so may cost you up to $250.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup> Your dog’s tags should include his name, and your phone number or street address.

<ul>
<li>You may also consider microchipping your dog to increase your chances of finding him/her if he/she runs away or gets lost. Your veterinarian can inject a microchip with a tracking number on it that can be scanned in the event that your dog gets lost and ends up in a shelter.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Grooming_Your_Dog_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Grooming_Your_Dog">Grooming Your Dog</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ec0d90b481" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ec0d90b481')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Wash-a-Dog" title="Wash a Dog">Wash your dog</a> as needed.</b> If your dog has short hair, give your dog a bath once every three months. If your dog has long hair, you may need to bathe him/her more often. To wash your dog, wet all of your dog’s fur with a spray hose or a pitcher, but do not wet the areas around his/her eyes, ears, and nose. Then, massage some shampoo into your dog’s fur. After you have worked the shampoo into a lather, rinse out all of the shampoo. The water should run clear and without suds. Then, dry him/her off with a towel.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Don’t use human shampoo on your dog, because some ingredients in human products can be irritating to dogs. Use a special dog shampoo when you wash your dog.</li>
<li>Offer your dog plenty of praise and a treat after baths to help him/her develop positive feelings about bath time.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_b4b0e1f930" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b4b0e1f930')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Brush-Your-Dog" title="Brush Your Dog">Brush your dog.</a></b> If your dog has short hair, you may only need to brush him/her once a week. If your dog has long hair, you will need to brush him/her every day in order to avoid tangled and matted fur. Use a wide comb to help remove tangles before moving on to a brush. Make sure that you offer your dog lots of praise while you brush him/her and give him/her a treat when you are finished so that he/she will be willing to let you brush him/her on a regular basis.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_0563d998ec" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0563d998ec')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/Clip-Dog-Nails" title="Clip Dog Nails">Clip your dog's nails.</a></b> To clip your dog’s nails, you will need to get a special nail clipper for dogs. You can purchase dog nail clippers in a pet store. You may also need to get your dog used to you handling his nails before you try to clip them. If your dog is wary of you touching his/her feet and nails, help him/her get used to it by petting his/her feet and touching his/her toes. Give him/her praise and a treat when he/she lets you touch his/her toes. After he/she becomes more comfortable with you touching his/her feet, you can try to clip his/her nails.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Make sure that you do not cut too far down or you may hit the quick of his/her nail. This area is very sensitive and may cause bleeding.</li>
<li>If you are concerned about hurting your dog while trimming his/her nails, ask your vet to show you how or have a professional groomer trim your dog’s nails for you.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-8.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_aec475d0cf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_aec475d0cf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-8.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Brush-a-Dog%27s-Teeth" title="Brush a Dog's Teeth">Brush your dog’s teeth.</a></b> Brushing your dog’s teeth can help to prevent problems with tooth decay and gum disease as your dog ages. If your dog has bad breath, it may indicate that there is excess bacteria causing a problem. Take your dog to have his/her teeth cleaned by a veterinarian and then follow your veterinarian’s instructions for cleaning his/her teeth.

<ul>
<li>You can use a child’s toothbrush, a gauze pad, or even a bit of nylon stretched over your finger to clean your dog’s teeth. Make sure that you use a special dog toothpaste or mix some baking soda with a bit of water to form a paste.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-9.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_2e1b018390" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2e1b018390')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-9.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Inspect your dog for problems during grooming times.</b> Grooming time is a good time to check your dog for fleas, ticks, and other potential health problems. Make sure that you inspect your dog’s skin for any unusual growths, wounds, or tender areas. You should also check your dog’s ears for excessive wax buildup and foul odors. If you find anything that seems abnormal, schedule an appointment with your veterinarian as soon as possible.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Feeding_Your_Dog_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Feeding_Your_Dog">Feeding Your Dog</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-10.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_2eeacbcbe6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2eeacbcbe6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-10.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand your dog’s dietary requirements.</b> The amount and frequency of your dog’s feedings will depend on the age and size of your dog. Talk to your veterinarian if you are unsure about how much you should be feeding your dog. In general, adult dogs only need to be fed once per day and the amount they need is based on their weight. You can usually find weight charts on dog food packages that indicate how much food your dog needs each day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Keep in mind that dogs under the age of one will need to be fed more frequently. Puppies from 8-12 weeks old need to be fed four times per day. They also require special puppy food. Check with your veterinarian to be sure that you are giving your dog the right type and amount of food every day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-11.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_5d5435a506" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5d5435a506')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-11.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make sure your dog always has access to fresh clean water.</b> Dogs need plenty of fresh clean water to drink every day. Your dog may need more water if he has been exercising or if the weather is hot. Make sure to provide a bowl of water that your dog can access easily. Refill it if the water gets low, and change the water daily.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-12.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_69832a46e2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_69832a46e2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-12.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Give treats for good behavior.</b> It’s nice to indulge your dog with a treat now and then to show that you care about him/her. Treats can be used to reward good behavior as well. Reward your dog with a treat every day, such as a dog biscuit or a rawhide bone.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Exercising_Your_Dog_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Exercising_Your_Dog">Exercising Your Dog</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-13.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_2854072567" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2854072567')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-13.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Walk your dog every day.</b> Dogs require daily exercise to be healthy and happy. Walking your dog every day is great way to help your dog get the exercise he/she needs. Your dog’s exercise needs will vary based on his/her breed, which means that some dogs will be content with a quick walk around the neighborhood, while others will require at least an hour of walking every day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Consider your dog’s energy level to determine how much and how often you should be walking him/her.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-14.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_a7a32f26de" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a7a32f26de')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-14.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Play with your dog.</b> Since not all dogs can do what they were bred to do, such as hunt or dig, it is important to play with them every day to keep them from forming destructive behaviors. Take your dog outside every day for a game of fetch or play tug of war with a special rope toy. Just make sure that you are doing something to stimulate your dog’s body and mind every day to prevent boredom.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-15.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_2ebdcac8a8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2ebdcac8a8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-15.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Give your dog plenty of opportunities to go outside.</b> In addition to daily walks and playtime, your dog may benefit from freedom to go outside a few times every day. An enclosed backyard or a long line are ideal so that your dog can run and explore his/her domain. If you let your dog out and do not join him/her outside, make sure to check on him/her from time to time.

<ul>
<li>If your dog often spends time outside during the warmer months, make sure that he/she has a shady place to get out of the sun and plenty of fresh, clean water and food.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Training_Your_Dog_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>5</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Training_Your_Dog">Training Your Dog</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_5">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-16.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_48b527a822" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_48b527a822')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-16.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider enrolling your dog in an obedience course.</b> Good dog owners put in the time and effort that is needed to train their dog basic commands. An obedience course can help you teach your dog some basic obedience skills such as sit, stay, and lay down. Going through an obedience course with your dog can also help you to build a better bond with your dog, which will benefit both of you.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You may also consider working one-on-one with a certified professional dog trainer. This is a good option if your dog is not a big fan of other dogs and people, or if you just want more attention and help from the trainer.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-17.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_3da82779f5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3da82779f5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-17.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep training sessions short and regular.</b> For the best results, train your dog in short sessions and repeat the sessions regularly. One way that you can train is by doing 5-15 repetitions of a behavior, such as teaching your dog to sit. Then, switch to a different behavior, and then another. Do these repetitions during one 15 minute session every day. Keeping training sessions short will help your dog pay attention. The frequency of your training sessions will help reinforce what you want your dog to learn.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-18.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-18.jpg" height="546" id="img_e0ceb92082" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e0ceb92082')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-18.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use positive reinforcement.</b> To teach your dog to do what you want him/her to do, it is important to reward his/her good behavior as soon as he does it. For example, if you ask you dog to sit and he/she does, praise and pet him/her right away so that your dog knows that he/she did something good. Try to reward your dog whenever he/she does good things so that he/she knows that these are the behaviors you like.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-19.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-19.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-19.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-19.jpg" height="546" id="img_c5e4530d6f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c5e4530d6f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-19.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-19.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ignore bad behavior.</b> Teach your dog to stop doing bad behaviors by ignoring him/her when he/she is naughty. For example, if your dog wants to go for a walk and he/she is jumping on you to let you know, ignore him/her and wait until he/she stops jumping. When he/she stops and stands still, put on his/her leash and take him/her for a walk. Repeat this process every time you walk your dog to help him/her understand that you do not want him/her to jump. He/she will learn that jumping up and down does not lead to a walk, but standing still does.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Never hit or scream at your dog if he/she does something bad. Punishing your dog in this way does not solve the problem and it may even make the problem worse.</li>
<li>Consult an animal behaviorist or certified professional dog trainer if you are having problems with training your dog.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Loving_Your_Dog_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>6</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Loving_Your_Dog">Loving Your Dog</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_6">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-20.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-20.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-20.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-20.jpg" height="546" id="img_6f8575cb11" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6f8575cb11')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-20.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-20.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Provide your dog with plenty of toys.</b> Good dog owners make sure that their dogs have toys to play with. Make sure that your dog has plenty of toys to keep him stimulated and happy. Some good options are chew toys, squeaky toys, rope toys, frisbees, and tennis balls. Find out what your dog likes best and make sure he/she has some favorite toys to play with at all times.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-21.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-21.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-21.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-21.jpg" height="546" id="img_c127430d08" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c127430d08')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-21.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-21.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Give your dog a soft spot to sleep every night.</b> Good dog owners don’t make their dogs sleep on the bare floor or outside in the cold. Make sure that you invest in a nice soft doggy bed for your dog when you first get him/her and line it with a blanket. Wash the blanket regularly to keep it clean and dry. Keep your dog’s bed in a warm part of the house that is free from drafts.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-22.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134528" href="#/Image:Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-22.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 22" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-22.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-22.jpg" height="546" id="img_7f79e4ba48" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7f79e4ba48')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Good Dog Owner Step 22" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-22.jpg/aid134528-v4-728px-Be-a-Good-Dog-Owner-Step-22.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Shower your dog with love and affection.</b> Dogs provide their humans with love, affection, and companionship, so why not return the favor? If you really want to be a good dog owner, make sure that you shower your dog with lots of love and affection. Pet him/her, praise him/her, and do nice things for him/her so that he/she knows that you care.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="148522" data-caid="149395" data-cqid="148539" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="973636" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="129" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="26">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Do I need to groom a short-coated dog such as an American Staffordshire terrier?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a><br/>
	Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons
</div>
Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Ideally yes. Use a rubber slicker as this will remove shed hair and at the same time massage his skin. Do this once a week and it helps spread the natural oils over his coat which gives a lovely seal-like gloss on the coat. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>26</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="211210" data-caid="212083" data-cqid="211227" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1333010" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="25">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="116651" data-caid="117524" data-cqid="116668" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="379002" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="40">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is it bad for me to keep my dog inside when I play baseball with my friends if I am afraid he will get hurt?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No, you're caring about your dog's health and well being. You know that he might get hurt, and it could lead to serious medical conditions.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="99502" data-caid="100375" data-cqid="99519" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="705180" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="26">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How much of my dog's nails should I trim off?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Take a small bit of the nail off to begin with, just a few millimeters.  The quick of the nail will recede as the nail grows shorter.  Cut frequently, but only a small amount at a time until they're the desired length.  </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>26</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="195928" data-caid="196801" data-cqid="195945" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1195279" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="19">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I clip my dog's nails if she is horrified of the clipper? She will literally run away from me when I try!</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Before you get your clipper in your hand, your dog needs to be able to trust you. You should wait for your pal to calm down and then try to touch their paws. Then you should hold their paw. After your dog lets you hold their paw with confidence and weeks of training, you can take the clipper. Then just carefully cut one nail, and reward your dog. If she lets you do it again, cut another nail. Don't try to cut too much at once. Try to make it a pleasant habit for you and your dog.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>19</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="199610" data-caid="200483" data-cqid="199627" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1040699" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="14">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My dog is a Boston terrier and has a very short nose. She can't breathe all that well when it is hot outside and when she runs around. How often should I take her for long walks and throw the ball?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">

<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Try playing fetch in a yard at night time (just make sure she is visible by using a reflective jacket, glow collar, or collar tag so cars don't hit her).</div>

</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="229456" data-caid="230329" data-cqid="229473" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1406669" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="16">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My dog doesn't hate bath time but certainly doesn't look forward to it. Any tips or tricks to make this more enjoyable (for both of us)? </div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer"> A little peanut butter or cream cheese spread along the walls of the tub can let Fido stay distracted enough to let you bathe him. Lots of praise and petting goes a long way, too.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>3</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>16</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="296951" data-caid="297824" data-cqid="296968" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1836750" data-submitter_id="2193425" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="16">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What can I do if my puppy will be left alone for 8-9 hours every day?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/2/20/2193425.jpg?20131124222710)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Laurenanswers">Laurenanswers</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Try to get a neighbor, family member, or friend to watch your puppy. If that isn't possible, hiring a dog walker or pet-sitter is highly recommended so that your puppy isn't left alone for such a long time. Another option is a doggie daycare. Do research to make sure that whoever you choose to watch your puppy is reliable, friendly, and experienced.</div>

<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="300748" data-caid="301621" data-cqid="300765" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1414906" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="8">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How long can I leave my dog in a crate? </div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Young dogs (6 months and under) shouldn't be left in a crate for more than 3-4 hours at a time. Older dogs can be left in a crate for up to 8 hours, but this can be taxing on your dog's mental and emotional well-being, so it's not recommended that you do this every day. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>8</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>If you only have one dog, consider socializing your dog with other friendly dogs. Look into doggy day care or a well-maintained dog park as a way to give your dog opportunities to play with other dogs.</li>
<li>Do not over-exercise your dog. You could hurt them!</li>
<li>If you have an idea of getting a dog, consider adopting one from an animal shelter near you.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>Remember that having a dog is a serious, long-term commitment. If you are not prepared to care for an animal for all of its natural life (about 10-20 years) then do <i>not</i> get a dog.</li>
<li>Never leave your dog outside for extended periods of time. Dogs need and want to be around people.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To be a good dog owner, take your dog to the vet for annual checkups and shots. You should also ensure your dog gets enough exercise by going for walks every day. To keep your pet healthy and happy, make sure your dog eats quality pet food, always has access to clean water, and has a cozy place to sleep each night. When training your dog, use positive reinforcement by giving treats and praise when your dog does what you want. Avoid hitting or yelling at your dog because these methods are ineffective. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For tips from our Veterinary reviewer on how to protect your dog's health, keep reading!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

<div class="section_text" id="article_info">
<p class="info author_info">This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>. Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.</p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Be a Good Dog Owner",
    "name": "Be a Good Dog Owner",

        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },

            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "aggregateRating": {
